title: 108_hr1662
content: The Act titled "Endangered Species Data Quality Act of 2004" emphasizes the importance of sound science by amending the definitions and general provisions of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The Act "Endangered Species Data Quality Act of 2004" amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 by defining key terms and specifying the use of best scientific and commercial data, including timely field survey data. The "Endangered Species Data Quality Act of 2004" amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 by emphasizing the importance of using empirical data that has been peer-reviewed and derived from timely field work. It also includes a conforming amendment to the table of contents. The "Endangered Species Data Quality Act of 2004" amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 by establishing criteria for scientific data to support listing species as endangered or threatened. It also addresses the use of field data in making these determinations. The "Endangered Species Data Quality Act of 2004" requires that data supporting the listing of a species as endangered or threatened must be obtained from timely field observations, including data from real property owners and operators. The "Endangered Species Data Quality Act of 2004" mandates the use of sound science in recovery planning, requiring the Secretary to identify and publish additional data in the Federal Register for any determination of a species as endangered or threatened. The regulation requires the Secretary to publish additional scientific and commercial data to assist in the preparation of a recovery plan for endangered species. Data submitted by the public will be considered by the recovery team and the Secretary in accordance with the Endangered Species Data Quality Act of 2004. The regulation requires peer review for scientific and commercial data to assist in the preparation of a recovery plan for endangered species. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include Independent Scientific Review Requirements for proposed determinations regarding endangered or threatened species. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include Independent Scientific Review Requirements for proposed determinations regarding endangered or threatened species. The term 'qualified individual' refers to someone with demonstrated scientific expertise on the development of recovery plans and determining actions that may jeopardize listed species. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include Independent Scientific Review Requirements for proposed determinations regarding endangered or threatened species. A 'qualified individual' must have scientific expertise relevant to the covered action, no conflict of interest, and not advocated a position on the outcome of the covered action. The Endangered Species Act is amended to include Independent Scientific Review Requirements for proposed determinations regarding endangered or threatened species. Conflict of interest is defined as direct financial interests in the outcome of the action, including consulting arrangements, grants, honoraria, or employment. The Secretary will solicit recommendations from the National Academy of Sciences and governors of affected States for qualified independent reviewers. The Secretary appoints 3 qualified individuals as independent scientific reviewers for covered actions. The reviewers will report on the scientific information and analyses without being subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Compensation may be provided if funds are available. The Secretary appoints 3 independent scientific reviewers for covered actions, who will review scientific and commercial data provided by the Secretary within 3 months. Compensation may be provided at the daily equivalent of the maximum annual rate of basic pay for GS-14. The Secretary appoints 3 independent scientific reviewers for covered actions to review data within 3 months. A notice of data availability is published before the final decision, allowing the public 15 days to provide additional information. The Secretary must identify and explain the best scientific and commercial data available for covered actions, including the reasons for their selection or exclusion. The Secretary evaluates independent reviews and includes a summary in the final determination. Reviews are included in the official record of the final decision on the action. The final decision on the action will be included in the official record and made available for public review. SEC. 4. IMPROVED CONSULTATION. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include the use of state information in consultations and provide governors with the opportunity to submit information for agency actions. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include the opportunity for individuals seeking authorization or funding from a Federal agency to participate in consultations regarding agency actions that may affect them. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to allow individuals seeking authorization or funding from a Federal agency to participate in consultations regarding the impact of proposed actions on species, including providing relevant information and discussing potential measures or alternatives. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to allow individuals seeking authorization or funding from a Federal agency to participate in consultations regarding the impact of proposed actions on species. This includes providing relevant information, discussing potential measures or alternatives, and requesting copies of the draft biological opinion used by the Secretary to develop the final biological opinion. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to allow individuals seeking authorization or funding from a Federal agency to participate in consultations regarding the impact of proposed actions on species. This includes providing relevant information, discussing potential measures or alternatives, and requesting copies of the draft biological opinion used by the Secretary to develop the final biological opinion. Individuals can also submit comments on the draft biological opinion and statement and discuss with the Secretary and the Federal agency the basis for any finding in the draft biological opinion and statement. If reasonable and prudent alternatives are proposed and not included in the final biological opinion, the Secretary must explain why. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to provide public access to information submitted for actions seeking authorization or funding. Comments and information will be maintained in a file by the Secretary and made available to the public, subject to specified exemptions. The title of the bill is amended to provide guidance on data use under the Act.
